block.p: I am writing to applaud the efforts of Joe Kelly for his Dads and Daughters organization (''Dad, Do You Think I Look Too Fat?'' Sept. 17). I was 27 when I finally received successful treatment for anorexia nervosa, after its first being diagnosed when I was 12.
The roots of my disease were multifaceted, but two major influences were my mother's own issues with food and my father's hypercriticalness, which often meant comments about my body.

I am writing to applaud the efforts of Joe Kelly for his Dads and Daughters organization (''Dad, Do You Think I Look Too Fat?'' Sept. 17). I was 27 when I finally received successful treatment for anorexia nervosa, after its first being diagnosed when I was 12.
The roots of my disease were multifaceted, but two major influences were my mother's own issues with food and my father's hypercriticalness, which often meant comments about my body.
I feel hopeful that the message Joe Kelly is sending will raise awareness and prevent young girls from sliding down a slippery slope that could lead to years and possibly decades of suffering.
